subject: history
title: From Rowlatt Act to Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (1919)
description: Timeline of repression that shattered Indian faith in British justice

phases.name: Rowlatt Committee Phase
phases.description: From committee formation to Act passage

phases.name: Satyagraha Movement
phases.description: Gandhi's nationwide resistance against Rowlatt Act

points: Justice Sidney Rowlatt (British judge) headed committee
Purpose: Investigate 'revolutionary conspiracies' and recommend legislation
Context: Revolutionary terrorism had been crushed by Defence of India Act (1915)
WWI ending; British wanted to make wartime repressive powers permanent
Committee had no Indian members
Indians not consulted
details.significance: First step toward permanent repressive legislation

points: Report submitted July 1918
Recommended draconian powers against 'sedition'
Proposed detention without trial
Trials without jury for political cases
Restriction on press freedom
Powers to search and arrest without warrant
details.indianReaction: Outrage among Indians; seen as continuation of wartime repression after war ended

events.title: Rowlatt Bills Introduced in Imperial Legislative Council
events.description: Two bills based on Rowlatt Committee recommendations

points: Two bills introduced by Viceroy Lord Chelmsford
Bill I: Against revolutionary conspiracies
Bill II: Against seditious activities
Provisions: Detention up to 2 years without trial; Trial without jury; Restrictions on movement and press
All Indian members of Council opposed
C. Sankaran Nair (Indian member) resigned in protest
British members used majority to pass
details.opposition: Unanimously opposed by all Indian members; protests across India

events.title: Rowlatt Act Passed (Black Act)
events.description: Draconian law passed despite total Indian opposition

points: Passed by Imperial Legislative Council (March 18, 1919)
Bill I became Rowlatt Act (Bill II dropped)
All Indian members voted against; walked out in protest
British members used majority to pass
Called 'Black Act' by Indians
Gandhi called it 'instrument of oppression'
provisions: Detention without trial for up to 2 years
Trial of political cases by special tribunals without jury
Provincial governments empowered to search and arrest without warrant
details.significance: Betrayed Indian expectations after WWI sacrifice; showed British unwillingness to trust Indians even after loyalty in war

events.title: Gandhi Announces Satyagraha
events.description: First all-India Satyagraha called against Rowlatt Bills

points: Even before Act passed, Gandhi announced resistance
Called for nationwide Satyagraha (civil disobedience)
Satyagraha Sabha formed to coordinate
Gandhi's first all-India political movement
Pledged to disobey 'unjust and tyrannical' law non-violently
Appeal to Viceroy to withdraw bills
details.significance: Gandhi's entry into all-India politics; first mass resistance movement under Gandhi

points: Gandhi called for nationwide hartal (strike) on March 30
Shops closed, people fasted and prayed
Mass meetings held
Observed mainly in Delhi and Punjab
Some violence in Delhi; clashes with police
British nervous about scale of protest
details.delhi: Processions and hartals; some violence led to police firing

events.title: Repression in Punjab Begins
events.description: Arrests of popular leaders; situation tense

points: Punjab saw strong protests against Rowlatt Act
Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew and Dr. Satyapal (popular local leaders) arrested (April 10)
Both Hindu (Satyapal) and Muslim (Kitchlew) leaders united in protest
Their arrest sparked massive protests in Amritsar
Lieutenant Governor Michael O'Dwyer ordered harsh repression
Punjab under martial law-like conditions
details.significance: Arrests of popular leaders inflamed Punjab; set stage for massacre

events.title: Second All-India Hartal (April 6)
events.description: More successful nationwide strike; Gandhi's leadership solidified

points: Originally planned for March 30 but rescheduled to April 6 for better coordination
Near-total hartal across India
Shops closed, work stopped, people gathered for prayers
Hindu-Muslim unity in protests
Unprecedented scale of peaceful mass protest
British alarmed by Gandhi's ability to mobilize masses
details.success: Demonstrated Gandhi's mass appeal; first successful all-India movement
details.issue: Some places saw violence; Gandhi worried about loss of non-violence

events.title: Violence in Delhi, Punjab, and Ahmedabad
events.description: Protests turned violent in some places

points: Delhi: Clashes between protesters and police; police firing
Punjab (Amritsar, Lahore): Violent protests after arrests of Kitchlew and Satyapal
Ahmedabad: Mill workers' protests turned violent; police firing killed 28
Telegraph lines cut, railway stations attacked in Punjab
British banks and buildings targeted
Several Europeans killed in mob violence (Punjab)
details.gandhiReaction: Gandhi deeply disturbed; felt he made 'Himalayan miscalculation' in launching mass movement without adequate preparation in non-violence

events.title: Gandhi Arrested, Prevented from Entering Delhi
events.description: Gandhi arrested while traveling to Delhi; released after few days

points: Gandhi traveling from Bombay to Delhi
Arrested at Palwal (near Delhi) on April 10
Taken back to Bombay and released
Prevented from going to Punjab or Delhi
British wanted to prevent his leadership in tense areas
details.aftermath: Gandhi's absence from Punjab meant no moderating influence during critical period

events.title: Martial Law Declared in Punjab
events.description: General Dyer takes command; repression intensified

points: Martial law declared in parts of Punjab including Amritsar
Brigadier General Reginald Dyer sent to Amritsar
Dyer given extraordinary powers
Ban on public meetings and processions
Shoot-on-sight orders for violators
Lieutenant Governor Michael O'Dwyer fully backed Dyer
Situation tense; British feared another 1857
details.dyer: Dyer was hardline officer who believed in maximum force; contempt for Indians

events.title: JALLIANWALA BAGH MASSACRE
events.description: British troops fire on unarmed gathering; hundreds killed

context: Public meeting called to protest Rowlatt Act and arrest of Kitchlew-Satyapal
Baisakhi fair also happening; many villagers in Amritsar
Jallianwala Bagh: Enclosed park/garden with narrow exits
About 10,000-20,000 people gathered (including women and children)
massacre: General Dyer arrived with 50 Gurkha and Balochi soldiers
WITHOUT WARNING, ordered troops to fire
1,650 rounds fired into densest parts of crowd
Many jumped into well (120+ bodies found in well)
Firing stopped only when ammunition exhausted
No medical help provided; wounded left to die

casualties.reality: Actual toll likely 1,000-1,500 killed; many more wounded

dyerJustification: Claimed he wanted to teach Indians a 'moral lesson'
Said he wanted to create 'moral and widespread effect'
Wanted to terrorize Indians into submission
No regret; said he would have used machine guns if available
Admitted he didn't warn crowd or ask to disperse
details.significance: Most brutal atrocity in Indian freedom struggle; shattered any remaining faith in British justice

events.title: Humiliating 'Crawling Order' & Martial Law Brutalities
events.description: Series of humiliating orders in Punjab

crawlingOrder: Lane where European woman (Miss Sherwood) was attacked
Dyer ordered all Indians passing through to crawl on bellies
Extreme humiliation and racial hatred displayed
details.purpose: Terrorize Punjab into submission; demonstrate British racial superiority
details.impact: Deep humiliation and resentment; radicalized even moderates

events.title: Gandhi Suspends Satyagraha
events.description: Gandhi calls off movement due to violence

points: Gandhi learned of violence in Delhi, Punjab, Ahmedabad
Announced suspension of Satyagraha (April 18)
Admitted 'Himalayan miscalculation'
Felt people not ready for mass civil disobedience
Needed more preparation in non-violence
Undertook fast as penance
details.criticism: Some criticized Gandhi for calling off movement; but he maintained non-violence non-negotiable
details.significance: Gandhi learned lessons; next movement (Non-Cooperation 1920) had better organization and discipline

points: Government appointed Disorders Inquiry Committee (Hunter Committee)
Lord Hunter (Scottish judge) chaired
Mixed British and Indian members
Task: Inquire into Punjab disturbances and Jallianwala Bagh
Hearings held Oct 1919 - March 1920
findings: Majority report (British members): Dyer exceeded authority but acted in good faith
Minority report (Indian members): Condemned Dyer and O'Dwyer strongly
details.dyer: Dyer dismissed from service but no criminal prosecution; got pension

events.title: British Parliament Debate - Dyer Defended
events.description: House of Lords supports Dyer; ¬£26,000 raised for him

points: Hunter Committee report debated in British Parliament
House of Commons: Condemned Dyer (but no prosecution)
House of Lords: Supported Dyer; called him 'savior of Punjab'
Morning Post (British newspaper) raised ¬£26,000 for Dyer
Presented to him as 'reward'
Dyer hailed as hero by many British
Kipling praised him
details.indianReaction: Outrage in India; British callousness exposed; showed racial attitudes; destroyed moderate faith in British
details.significance: British support for Dyer convinced even moderates that self-rule essential

points: Rabindranath Tagore (Nobel laureate, poet) had been knighted (1915)
Shocked by Jallianwala Bagh Massacre
Wrote letter to Viceroy renouncing knighthood (May 30, 1919)
Condemned 'frightfulness' and 'inhumanity'
Called for atonement
details.quote: 'The time has come when badges of honour make our shame glaring in the incongruous context of humiliation'
details.significance: Symbolic protest by India's most respected cultural figure; inspired others

events.title: Congress Amritsar Session - Condemns Massacre
events.description: Congress demands accountability; prepares for stronger action

points: Congress session held at Amritsar (Dec 1919) - symbolic location
Passed resolution condemning Punjab atrocities
Demanded punishment for Dyer and O'Dwyer
Appointed own inquiry committee (led by Madan Mohan Malaviya, C.R. Das)
Mood turned against British government
Prepared ground for Non-Cooperation Movement
details.significance: Even moderates radicalized; consensus building for strong action against British

events.title: Khilafat Issue Emerges
events.description: Muslim anger over treatment of Turkish Caliph; Gandhi sees unity opportunity

points: Post-WWI: Ottoman Turkey defeated; Caliph's position threatened
Indian Muslims concerned about Caliph (spiritual head)
British harsh treatment of Turkey angered Muslims
Khilafat Committee formed (1919)
Ali Brothers (Maulana Mohammad Ali, Shaukat Ali) led movement
Gandhi saw opportunity for Hindu-Muslim unity
Connected Rowlatt-Jallianwala Bagh anger with Khilafat grievance
details.gandhiStrategy: Gandhi decided to join Khilafat movement to unite Hindus and Muslims for Non-Cooperation
details.significance: Set stage for combined Khilafat-Non-Cooperation Movement (1920)

summary.title: Overall Impact and Significance
summary.devastation: Rowlatt Act + Jallianwala Bagh Massacre + Crawling Order + British support for Dyer = Complete destruction of Indian faith in British justice
transformation: Demand shifted from reforms to complete independence
Prepared psychological ground for mass movements
gandhiEmergence: Gandhi emerged as undisputed mass leader
His Satyagraha method proved powerful (despite violence)
Combined Rowlatt-Jallianwala anger with Khilafat issue
legacy: Jallianwala Bagh became symbol of British brutality
Martyrs' blood fueled freedom struggle for decades
1919 was turning point - no going back to pre-war trust
Independence became inevitable from this moment

mustRemember: Provisions: Detention without trial for 2 years; Trial without jury
Gandhi's first all-India Satyagraha against Rowlatt Act
General Dyer fired 1,650 rounds; 379 official deaths (1,000+ actual)
Dyer fired without warning for 10 minutes; only stopped when ammunition exhausted
Hunter Committee: Dismissed Dyer but no criminal trial
British Parliament and public supported Dyer; ¬£26,000 raised
